My only regret is that I split the filet and the scallops with someone and the scallops, while good, didn't hold a candle to the filet.  Good wine selection, too.  Next time I am in Vegas, will definitely be making the trek over to the Wynn.

QuBySWERinoieQboNuaHgQ.text: Excellent. The food was amazing. We all got the grilled beet and goat cheese dish and oh my goodness I could eat that more often for sure! I also got the spicy artichoke flatbread, AMAZING German wheat beer that tasted wheaty and banana-y. We all enjoyed ourselves, and the restaurant has a nice atmosphere.

odYqWGdeH1PSxvHlHtnGFg.text: Looked toYelp for a spot to grab an elegant and affordable meal. All the positive reviews of this place are spot on. Beautiful patio seating overlooking the pool (inside is very accurate to the name. It is dark and feels like a wine cellar), the food is fantastic and prices are very reasonable. I shared the beet salad, green bean salad, egg over easy sandwich, and flatbread pizza (don't remember all the formal names) with a gf. Those dishes, combined with a drink for each of us came out to $80. Not bad at all!  We were full with leftovers to spare.  The only reason I am not giving 5 stars us because of the beet dish. It was much too salty!!! We couldn't get past several bites.  Make sure to try the strawberry wheat beer. Soooo good.

bB31lW12ARTHCJL4dZH5qA.text: Rounded up from 2 1/2*  Nice atmosphere/design--feels like a Spanish cava cellar--and attentive service.  But, the mixed green and shaved goat cheese salad is one of the most horrific salads I've ever had--bitter, unbalanced and possibly not-so-fresh greens.  The glass of pinot grigio was decent, and people seemed to be enjoying food other than the offending salad.

-WDFsjdkQiHu9qznl4KfFw.text: Very cool place - We were in Vegas for 4 days and hit this place 3/4 of them.  Marvin the Bartender was excellent and took great care of us multiple times.  Made us a few concoctions that weren't on the menu based off our requests, and was great about advice in the area for other places/things to do.    Patio: Great sitting outside on the patio overlooking the pool / grounds.  Very peaceful and relaxing.  Not a huge place, but definitely a spot I want to go to relax and have a good drink.  Food: Seriously awesome food.  We never came here for dinner, but more for lunch/place to relax for a bit, so it was never very busy.  We had the charcuterie plate multiple days, and for $36, it's an absolute steal.  You get a ton of meat/cheese, and its all very fresh and well done.  The hot coppa was my favorite by far.  Additionally, we tried the pasta with the fried egg on top which was one of our favorite pastas on the trip believe it or not, as well as their steak flatbread which was perfect.  10/10 on food - Didn't expect that, but it was awesome.  Overall, can't recommend this place enough.  It's quiet, nice, great staff, and unbelievable food and drink.

mpvx3PHiHkc0NDv3AQeHiw.text: Very cozy little hide out perfect to chill with a glass of wine!

photos.caption: Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States

67i4qgzy-y8_ElySXVONGw.text: We just ate at La Cave for the first time. We will definitely back again, and next time with more friends. Aldana was our server, excellent service. Food was amazing and we will be back soon!

pcmGo26IyCbyc4koPhUcZg.text: Great little hideout within the Wynn. We booked this place because we were watching Le Reve at 7:00pm and thought we'd grab an early dinner before then.  FOOD: Ordered their La Cave Caesar Salad ($11.00), Onion Soup ($9.00), Shrimp Ceviche ($15.00), Tomato, Micro Mozzarella, Caper Flatbread ($14.00), Black Angus Sirloin Steak ($22.00), Rack of Lamb ($23.00), Strowngbow Apple Cider ($9.00), Strawberry Cucumber Lemonade ($16.00), and a Chocolate Mousse Cake ($9.00).  The La Cave Caesar is marvelous little appetizer to start off dinner, it's Bibb lettuce wrapped in a thinly sliced Prosciutto with lightly brushed on Caesar dressing. I really enjoyed it since it wasn't so heavy with dressing and the Prosciutto was the perfect amount to give a nice savory kick to the fresh lettuce. The Shrimp Ceviche was a little sweet for me since the peach and pineapple chutney has a really sweet undertone, but shrimps were crunchy and definitely cleaned well. Their flatbread I think was highlight of the dinner in terms of portion and price, especially in Vegas upscale restaurants. It's enough to feed two people at least and visually it's not overly oily like normal pizzas are. My sister and brother seemed to really enjoy the texture and the how the flavors were light and flavorful. The Black Angus Sirloin is to die for! I definitely recommend it. It was so tender and juicy, cooked to perfection that it melted in my mouth when I ate it. Ahhh! I can still taste the delicious aroma of their Sirloin steak!  SERVICE: Our waitress was absolutely lovely, my sister has difficulty making up her mind when it comes to deciding on a dish, but she was patient with us and was just terrific. Great attitude with a charming smile and bright personality! She wasn't overly pushy in terms of over checking up on us nor did she disappear the entire time we were dining.  AMBIANCE: Just spectacular! I made a reservations note that I wanted to sit in their garden patio and that was where we were seated. Our seats were more like front porchesque couches where you get to sit back with long comfy pillows all around as you sip wine and look at the beautiful view of Vegas through their glass patio. Soft jazz music gingerly danced in the background with dimmed lighting, noise level was minimal which I loved. It's so classy and romantic here! Perfect for intimate outings. :)

gkU86fcxVae8wNKXxnGXtg.text: I like small plates, tapas, shareables, etc. La Cave has been on my list for a while. We we're not that hungry, but because we were near, we decided to stop in at the bar and try it out.   We only tried four apps, which was plenty for us. The couple next to us, suggested the Jumbo lump crab lettuce cups. Great crabmeat and crispy lettuce, No complaint on the freshness, just very simple to the point that you wanted something more. It needed a touch of lemon or yuzu aioli or just something to bring it together. A little more thought into this dish, and it would have been great.   We tried the the Salmon sashimi tostada. This was also good, but simple. Although 3 small pieces for $15 seemed to be a bit steep, even at Vegas prices.   We sampled the Bacon wrapped dates, with blue cheese fondue. Wrapped dates with a blue cheese dipping sauce. Pass on this one. You've seen it a bunch of times. It's tired.  Finished with the Diver sea scallops on polenta cake. Very good.  La Cave deserves another try. I'm sure there's plenty of dishes that would blow me away. The apps, although good, were just not knock you off the stool great.   They have a very aggressive wine list, and lots of wine by the glass, but the wines are definitely not cheap. I know, it's Vegas, and it's the Wynn, but it would be nice to not be gouged on wine, at every place on the strip. But I guess that makes them all consistent I guess.

9qL5CFmZD8zsW14jjH6jqA.text: If you go keep in mind it is pricey and they serve tapas. Once that's out of the way, the food was good. The ambience is romantic and pleasant. It is very dim in there. I'd go back

n3bUljAsnstMXENm0sxZ4Q.text: La Cave is amazing. The private room, which opens to an outdoor patio, is fantastic as well. Most importantly, the sliders at La Cave are the best I have ever had in my life.   This statement is not hyperbole. In fact, the mini-burgers were so good that I stuffed myself by eating two orders (half a dozen)!  The shrimp is also solid, but nothing to get too enthusiastic about. The only reason this is not a five star review is that I found the shrimp to be a huge step down from the burgers. I will have to return to do additional research.

pgiF8TrXnm21H0lJ6fjg7w.text: Five Stars all the way.  Have been to La Cave on a few different occasions. All different, but all just as excellent.  In short, the food is all tapas style and everything is delicious. Do share a few different things. And if you are like me, do order two of the crab citrus lettuce wraps....  The wine is phenomenal. Their selection is great and they have the best wine flights I have ever had. Personally, I only order from their wine flights, so that I can get a few different tastes of the wines I like versus just focusing on one.  Their Sunday Brunch is truly an experience. Everything is served in small plates, and there is no menu. Waiters just continue to come by with different options and you can get as many different things as you like. For $30 you can also add bottomless mimosas, bloody Mary's or Caipirinhas. Overall, an awesome deal for the quality and quantity you get. (Just ask my mother in law and her sister, who in their 70's can throw back more of these drinks than any 20-something.)  If it is a nice day, make sure to ask to sit out on the patio. It is gorgeous!

DqQ-Q73wdRRppP_z4dQTKQ.text: This is my favorite place in Vegas.   We start off with Caesar salad with extra anchovies. Bacon wrapped dates is good too. My husband and I always get 3 orders of beef carpaccio and truffle fries. Best beef carpaccio I've ever tried.   S'mores flatbread for dessert. A meal is not complete without a dessert.   Brunch is also great. Better than a buffet.   Service is always great. La Cave is love.

plG3XzGorvyaZAxgGoZumA.text: Went with 2 other couples.  We got a ton of tapas.  Everything was just ok, nothing was amazing.  Even the flight of wine was just ok.  The service was good and the price point was spot on.

POwWsssE1ztJ9e5XpA99pQ.text: We stopped by on Saturday afternoon for a pre-dinner snack after hanging out at the pool.   We were seated right away on their patio which overlooks the pool.  It was 112 degrees that day but they had water misters all throughout the patio which kept us cool.   Our group of 3 shared the following dishes and really enjoyed each one: Salmon Sashimi Tostada - refreshing combination of ingredients Mini Burgers - the beef was perfectly cooked and juicy! Bacon and Egg Fettucini - very flavorful and rich  Beet and Cheese Dish (I forget the name) - it came out in a cute mini cast iron pan and was the perfect summer dish! This was perfect to hold us over until our dinner reservation.  The service was great and the food came out quickly.

iDT6st-tNWVG_PiuRtvWVw.text: One star is too high for this place. Rich (the manager) is terrible, zero communication skills or customer service. Save your money and go elsewhere. Not worth it unless you like being insulted and asked to leave halfway through your desert to make sure they make money on the next table.

GeJdTVJGGjDuV5I6DuMoKg.text: My husband and I stopped by for a mid-day bite (we have dined here before) and once again the serive and food undoubtably deserves a 5 star rating. We sat at the bar and our bartender, Marv, was so incredibly pleasant when I accidentally ordered a dish that was not what the dish I intended to order. He immediately exchanged the dish in the most friendly and nice manner. Marv actually brought back the roasted beet dish that was ordered in error and offered it to us to enjoy, it was amazing. Marv raises the bar! Thank you Marv and La Cave The Wynn raises the bar as well, our favorite hotel in Vegas.

2qOCC66cEeI5X3mQcAfJLA.text: Seated at the bar, excellent friendly service from host to bartender. Very friendly and welcoming. Drinks were expensive and served in smaller glasses with a stingy pour.

UlH1-HZqmS18bS1UZByUYg.text: La cave is a restaurant located in the Wynn that serves interesting tapas.   We started with crab rolls in lettuce, which I thought were tasty but under seasoned. Overall a forgettable dish.   Next came the Wagyu slider on zucchini, which was juicy and delicious. I wholeheartedly recommend this dish.   Next came the carbonara with sunny side up egg and fried prosciutto. the prosciutto was delicious; crispy and salty, but the rest of the dish fell short. The pasta was delightfully chewy, and the egg was well cooked, but the dish felt under seasoned overall. This is the second time I felt that the seasoning was off.   Next came the scallop and polenta. The scallop was incredible--cooked and seasoned to perfection, but the polenta was flaky and again under seasoned. It was cooked well, however.   Next came the Thai snapper ceviche with lotus root. The root was crispy and light, and the fish Ceviche was an excellent pair. I felt the overall flavour was safe, not exciting.   The beef filet was well cooked, but again the flavours were on the safe side. The blue cheese was a good compliment, and the truffle cream was on the sour side. Well cooked, average seasoning    We rounded off the meal with a charcuterie plate of sopressata, prosciutto, and aged Gouda. This was the best dish of the meal. Lavash, aged Gouda, and the jam, combined with the cured meats created an incredible flavour medley unlike anything I've ever had.  The last dish alone bumped this review from 3-4, along with amazing attentive service and an enjoyable, laid back environment. For the cost, I feel the food was held back in one way or another, which kept La Cave from scoring 5 stars with me. However, if you're a fan of tapas and fancy wine and cheese, be sure to stop by La Cave

photos.caption: Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crab cakes in lettuce wrap
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wagyu skirt steak on a bed of zucchini
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Carbonara with egg and prosciutto

H55BfEKwsdUqEELnOZZxWg.text: Had high hopes about the food for Sunday brunch. Honestly, I'm a bottomless brunch addict and this sounded great, being butler style and all. Service was subpar. Boyfriend and I got seated and didn't even have one person come up to us for over 5 minutes. Almost got up and left. Cocktails were okay. At least you have options other than typical champagne during brunch. Stick with the white sangria, can't go wrong with that. Also, notice they'll obviously walk around with all the high carb, cheaper foods. Pretty sure pancakes came by our table over 15 times. None of the good stuff came until we asked them. Like I said, subpar service. Wouldn't recommend going here unless you wanna really blow $160 plus tip for two people and starve while you wait for the real food to come out.

photos.caption: Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Don&#39;t get your hopes up for the good stuff to ever come out. Make sure you ask them.
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mushroom grits was amazing. Only good thing on their brunch menu. Skip the flavorless French toast pictured below grits.

eRBMnK4sDEgJDXACWc2NeA.text: We went to La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway on 9/13/18.  Our bill was $210 for 4 people -- the food was good, but let's face it this is still pretty expensive for a charcuterie board, 3 tapas, 1 desert, 1 alcoholic drink and one or two non-alcoholic drinks.  The price isn't what bothered us though.  As I said, our bill was $210, but when our waiter brought the bill and my husband's credit card back to the table, we were charged $185 -- it was a $25 difference, so while we wondered if it was a mistake and were going to ask, we also thought it might have been some sort of comp for some reason.  But then the waiter came back and asked for my husband's card again (which he still had out, just in case) -- the waiter had used the card to pay the wrong bill.  So now he charges us $210.  But what we didn't find out until the next morning was that the restaurant did not cancel the  previous authorization for $185.  The waiter never told us that would happen and no manager came to tell us this -- I guess we were just supposed to know this or something.  So my credit card sits there for 3-5 days with both charges on it, until the bank clears the authorization -- tying up an extra $185 of my money while we are on vacation -- while this may be no big deal for their usual clientele of millionaires and billionaires, it is a big deal to a regular person.  We didn't find out that both charges stayed on the card until the next morning, and when my husband called the restaurant and spoke to a manager, he basically could have cared less.  Yes, I got a "Sorry", but that was it.  My husband has built a Customer Experience program for a Fortune 200 company, and he was completely ticked off by this point.  Nothing but a sorry -- that is really sorry.  No offer to comp one of our dishes or the difference between the bills ($25) or the amount of the tip for the waiter who never told us anything about this happening ($42).  After mentioning this, the manager did provide a flippant offer to comp a drink, so my husband asked if that included the $2,500 bottle of wine on the menu -- no response.  I guess you have to be a millionaire or billionaire and/or a celebrity for La Cave or Wynn to care whether you had a positive customer experience.  If you are Joe Blow, you just don't matter enough for them to care about your customer experience.  Won't be going here again, and if you aren't a millionaire or billionaire and/or a celebrity, I suggest you don't go either -- this place just doesn't give a flying leap about the middle class -- it was obvious to us our customer experience just wasn't important to them.

hNOsT8n_YhQ41McCmgA87w.text: The No1DP found this restaurant as a recommendation from the Encore concierge as a restaurant with portions and environment friendly for single travelers. Though it makes for the concierge to make a recommendation within the hotel, the No1DP had a nice meal out of it. When I joined him several days later he took me here on our first dinner date before the AWS re:Play party.  LOCATION: One of the restaurants that line the Wynn Esplanade, the shopping strip inside the Wynn/Encore.  We got to sit right next to the kitchen where all the hot items were grilled and the flatbreads were baked. We got to talk to one of the chefs and we witnessed how they prepared some of our food.   - Diver Sea Scallops, Polenta Cake, Shrimp Sauce ($18). Medium-sized juicy scallop with an equal portion of polenta, which is easily becoming one of my favorite presentations of cornmeal. The small plate is deceptive that eating the entire plate could get a person full quite quickly. - Mushroom Grits, Pecorino ($10). Though not a lot of mushrooms it had full of mushroom flavor. It was also the most carb-heavy dish so I was able to get more full because of my portion of grits. It's served in a cask-iron skillet to keep it hot.  - La Cave Caesar, Prosciutto, Lemon Anchovy Dressing ($11). Several stalks of lettuce doesn't make it a salad. It's essentially lettuce wrapped in prosciutto and served with a savory cream puff. It's a decent attempt at interpreting caesar salad as a small plate. - Prawns, Baby Corn, Long Beans, Chili Vinaigrette ($18). We got to see this made right in front of us from the grilling of shrimp to its final assembly of baby corn and long beans. This dish is meant to be eaten whole as the individual components are just average. Shrimps were a big portion. - Beef Filet, Caramelized Onions, Mushrooms, Blue Cheese Flatbread ($17). Our dining companion of the night offered me a slice of flatbread. The flour used is double zero, a high-quality flour used for making pastas and pizzas. I took a bite of the beef and it was soft yet packed with so much mushroom flavor. If the No1DP was used to eating beef he would certainly enjoy it. If dining for two flatbread can get you full quite quickly so we're glad in retrospect that we got non-flatbread dishes - it allowed us to try more small plates.  Server was knowledgable in our requests of wine glasses for the night. No1DP enjoyed his white while I was happily sipping my light Pinot Noir.   The place is definitely pricey (as is all Vegas establishments) but a reliably good restaurant for small plates.

photos.caption: Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mushroom grits
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Jumbo shrimp
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Caesar salad

lJ7G1W1Erye0kcfo5uIRng.text: Love Spanish Tapas? Not here. The classic exotic flavors you would normally enjoy are vacant and lack a full menu for a variety of eating lifestyles. These American fusion-styled tapas are highly expensive for mediocre small portions of food. La Cave is tucked away inside the Wynn with modern industrial styles with really dark lighting.  My boyfriend and I went here for a friends birthday and were seated in the bar area which was really dark and busy. There was another room enclosed that could of been used for our 12 person party yet we were in the not-so-great area. Ask for the glass room for reservations and make sure to request a non-bar sitting area. At least the service was decent and the hostesses were helpful.  The wine list was extensive with reds, whites, dessert wines, sparkling, bubbly and even orange wines (still not sure what those entail?) that range from $16 to the hundreds by glass. The cucumber ginger cocktail was refreshing!   I ordered the Onion Soup for $12; it was alright. My boyfriend loves steak and always orders it,  so we always rate them 1-10! He ordered the skirt steak which was cut in pieces for $26 and gave it a 7 out of 10.  If you want to spend a bit less with top notch classic Tapas, go to Firefly Tapas on Paradise Road. Off of the Strip, it is well worth your time and money and your taste buds! (P.S. The steak was rated 11 there!)

ko40gbplErsIPxU7LEszvQ.text: Rule #1: Request PATIO seating or else you're just not doing your meal justice. The patio is beautiful and overlooks one of the Wynn's smaller private pool.   Service is friendly and excellent overall. The food tastes yummy too. They are known for their flat breads here -- also the best bang of your buck items for sharing. All other items smaller, tapas style. The menu offers a wide variety of healthy choices that are not too heavy or fatty. I really like the Wagyu -- sliced thinly, tender, and cooked perfectly medium rare. The fish are good too -- salmon and halibut were cooked well.   Great dining place in Vegas if you're looking for somewhere fancy, reasonable pricing, great views and service, and healthy to chillax and get your conversations on away from The STRIP.

photos.caption: Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Birthday cake :)
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chorizo and Italian flatbread was yummy and spicy
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Special of the night: sea bass

Tf6ZwLZ9P1ZZSMadgUk16A.text: Their pasta was so terrible I couldn't eat it.  It was complete mush (this was the bacon and egg fettuccini), and I would have actually preferred to eat a boxed kraft product over this.... I would not ever say that, so that's how bad it was.  In retrospect, I should have sent the dish back.    I will say that they had an excellent wine flight, which is good since I wasn't eating.  :(

kJf2n3aSaegwMFCbQ2t-lw.text: This review is based solely on the service, not the food.  Usually I associate casino restaurants with the height of service, especially the Wynn, but the hostesses really chapped my ass.  My Wife & I were meeting family for dinner. We arrived a bit later than our family, so were trying to meet up asap. The hostesses did not greet persons going in before us, and were deep in convo. We looked at each other confused & assumed it was a casual place, so we took a step inside too. Maybe that's the etiquette here? No one asked us anything. We never intended to be rude barbarians. We saw our family waiting, when the hostess briskly walked up to us, physically blocked our path demanding, "EXCUSE ME, CAN I HELP YOU, DO YOU HAVE A RESERVATION!". We felt so embarrassed - "Yes, *surname here*, we have a reservation, that's our family right over there". She wasn't believing still. Were we underdressed? Do we not belong? "WELL, I CAN -TAKE- YOU THERE,", she quipped.  K, B-tch, you do that. "Hi & welcome" also works well.  We felt so embarrassed & selfconscious as we sat down, not even an apology for the spectacle. Our family could see our upset.  Proceed to the waitress effing up our whole table's order & laying on the flirt with men at the table like spackle. I wouldn't have given a s*** if our order was correct, but she seriously missed like 3 entrees for the table. That's pretty bad. I understand it would be advantageous to flirt for a bachelor party or something, but it honestly made me & the other ladies at the table uncomfortable because it was all family & that man was our Dad, husband, brother, etc...and she was crouching down intimately...you get the idea.  Anyhow, the hostesses took the cake that night for making us feel like utter doodoo. Gracias.

wUySXtHjh4lXz9uGWOAGdw.text: La Cave is nice cozy spot to eat for lunch or dinner. Their food is tapas style so most of the entrees are meant for sharing or are of a smaller portion size. Pretty moderately priced too! It's also got a nice patio. Unfortunately since I didn't make a reservation for dinner, they sat me down at one of their bistro tables inside which still had a nice view of the pool outside. I ordered their Roasted Salmon but knowing that it probably wouldn't be enough to fill me up, I went with my server's recommendation and ordered the Hamachi Cubes for my appetizer. Hamachi Cubes -- Yuzu Aioli, Crispy Lemon Chip bit.ly/11dvgs1 Very fancy dish! It was too pretty to eat! But the bite sized cubes were very good! The Yuzu Aoili made it very flavorful. Roasted Salmon -- Vegetable Pasta, Yellow Tomato Broth bit.ly/Z3gBmY I guess I underestimated the portion size on the salmon. It was a pretty generous portion! The salmon was cooked perfectly and I liked the vegetable pasta that went along with it. While it may not look like much on the picture, it was a very hearty entree and I was very satisfied! Service was exceptional and on point! My server was very good and she always checked up on me and also very knowledgeable about the menu. She definitely earned a nice tip! Although I didn't get to eat out on the nice patio, I still had a nice dining experience at La Cave. I must come back again to try their flatbreads and all the other entrees. It's top notch dining on a very affordable budget!! 5 Stars!!

photos.caption: Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Roasted Salmon
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Hamachi Cubes

nqqX8d9sAyVhBNyep01jZQ.text: I love La Cave. It's a little hideaway in the Wynn that has the decor and feel of dining in a wine cellar. The tables are too close together, I am not a fan of tables too close together when dining in an intimate setting. The food was very good. It's a great place to go to share lots of small dishes in a tapas style fashion.

nTpFDB-p_p1enLX2zMba4A.text: We came to vegas as a party of 6 right around new years, and had our first dinner at La Cave. What can I say? The food was incredible, the drinks were incredible, the service was outstanding. We ordered around 20 dishes brought out a few at a time, and sampled a large portion of the menu, and there wasn't a single item any of us were unhappy with. We ate and drank for at least 3 hours, and went back to our hotels stuffed to the max. Will have dinner again here next time we are in Vegas.

ZOLhCqWk5Q5Oyat0pN2IGA.text: We were in Vegas to see Duran Duran.  It was my fourth time seeing them.  Yes...I am quite the Duranie.  We were staying at the Wynn (5 star review forthcoming) and decided to eat at La Cave since it's in the hotel.  I like the idea of small plates and sampling a lot of different things instead of one giant entree.    We both ordered the bacon and egg fettuccini and I think that came first.  It was very good.  The bf wolfed it down in a second.  I was savoring mine...Then he ordered the BBQ pulled pork flat bread.  DELICIOUS.  The pork was tender and not dry; it was full of flavor.  I ordered the mini burgers and every single bite of that was HEAVEN.  It was so perfectly seasoned...ever little bite I took.    To drink I ordered a red wine flight which I found to be very pleasant.  He ordered just a glass of zin and it was also in my flight.    I can't say enough good things abut the Wynn.  They do it up right.  Even us common-folks can enjoy a little slice of decadence.  It's great.

mEvXCseyIpqSmdKAhwomxQ.text: One of my favorite Sunday Vegas indulgences is the covered patio at La Cave.  When we have nowhere to be and nothing that has to be done I love spending a late afternoon enjoying the fantastic wine selection and watching the reflection of the sunset in the side of the bronze windows of the Wynn.  The service is just perfect.  The check in often enough to make sure our glasses are refreshed with cold Champagne, but give us enough room to get lost in conversation.    If you're lucky enough, you might score one of the swing seats along the far wall.  My personal favorite spot to sit is along the back wall on the long comfy couches, safely protected from the sun but not the views.  If brunch is your plan, they have a fun Sunday brunch that is served butler style.  Servers carry tapas style brunch dishes on serving platters and stop by to offer each table.  I like that the brunch is a set fee, so you can just relax and focus on the moment.  They also have a bottomless drink offering that includes multiple cocktails.  I must confess that their bloody mary needs some work.

photos.caption: Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Charcuterie (from left to right) - Aged Gouda Landana, Sopressata, Truffle Temor, Hot Coppa, Felino, P&#39;tit Basque
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The view from the La Cave patio

ylgzvA_ht_d50lse0d-EOw.text: If you want a great meal with the best wait staff this will be your place.  Sitting at the bar or the outside patio is our favorite place to dine. Can't go wrong with anything on their menu, everything is delicious. But I would highly recommend the beets with goat cheese.  Truly amazing!!!

photos.caption: Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Excellent bar service with great wine selection
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beets with warm goat cheese and pistachios
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The beets with goat cheese is a must!

nASfgMraYdHDK_rwk4X48Q.text: The worst service I never had at Vegas . The waitress here is so mad . It feels like he doesn't even talk to me as a customer. I feel fully discriminate from that Philippine guy .

0RL9wm7lQykvcGOH4YWS3Q.text: I had a very mixed experience here and leaving 1 star for the way my issue was handled. Will never be back.  I went there with a group of 5 for wine and snacks. Even though most of place was empty, we had a hard time getting a table because the host said the table was reserved.. 2.5 hours later. We were finally able to argue we had a flight to catch and promised to be gone in 2 hours. That was fine, we had decent service and enjoyed the wine menu. The food was unremarkable though and wines by the glass list wasn't very special. We had several bottles of wine from the bottle list. And a few bland whites from the BTG list.  What happened next is what irks me, we had a bill of several hundred dollars and split the check 5 ways. Later when I got home I realized I was over charged on my card by over $10 on the tip, even though I left 22% tip for a mediocre guest experience. I called and they asked that I send a picture of the receipt and what not, which I did. I never heard anything back for almost a month and figured they fixed it because no one said anything. I checked my account and nothing, wrote asking why I still wasn't credited, and the manager wrote back saying "he had called me and left a message saying I needed to call back with my cc#".  Well I never got a call. I checked my missed calls for the past month and there's been nothing, plus my VM box has been full since October so it's impossible he ever left a message like he stated. I don't appreciate being lied to. And I don't understand why no one simply responded to my email for me to call back. Either way it was irritating and I called back and asked for the over charge as well as the rest of my tip to be refunded. He said that's impossible, none of it. Then offered no explanation or apology for what happened, for it taking so long to fix, for lying about calling and resolving the issue with the absolute bare minimum. Excellent job Aaron!

zlu__w0tnnYBhRCR2KSH0Q.text: I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet!  I had dined at La Cave a year ago with 5 of my girlfriends to celebrate my bachelorette weekend. Everything at La Cave was amazing - my girlfriends and I still talk about it fondly.  Walking to La Cave itself was such an experience. It is located inside the Wynn. We had to walk through the gorgeous hallways and then arrive at La Cave, where we were seated promptly.  We had ordered a whole array of tapas to share, including the roasted beets, bacon-wrapped dates, ceviche, salmon tostada, beef and blue cheese flatbread, sirloin steak, etc. Everything was incredibly delicious! Each one of us was in love with the food, including one or two picky eaters!  Three of us got a wine flight as well. I LOVE wine flights, and this one didnt disappoint! To pair with the wine flight, we ordered three types of cheese to share. Oh man, the portions we got! BIG pieces of cheese! We were all giddy with happiness because we thought we'd get an inch at most, considering what a reasonable price it was.   The service was super friendly and polite. We all had an amazing time laughing, sharing food and indulging in good wine. Thank you La Cave for the good memories and for making sure the last dinner on my bachelorette trip was a success! :)

oJPX1n6t1yey4cCoR80EUA.text: My son and i ate there Saturday night service was good food excellent just very small portions next time I'm bring my midget friend since everything is small portions

nKBe8VHPprMVFLpwAINEkA.text: I was so excited to eat here; great reviews and we walked through at lunchtime. It smelled great and was beautiful. But upon arriving we were seated at a table under a gigantic tv that was blaring horrible white blue light throughout the room! It was awful! Too expensive for such a horrible dining experience!

ccnvF5R-THUA9Bi0CRC4Qw.text: Sitting at the bar here is a great spot for a solo diner. It's hidden away, dark and feels private. The bartenders were super friendly! I enjoyed bacon wrapped dates (OMG!), shrimp and a cavatelli dish, along with a few glasses of wine from their excellent selection. Just like any Vegas casino eatery, the prices are steep. My 3 small tapas dishes came out to $50 (not including alcohol or tip). Luckily it was on the company's dime. If I were to visit here again, I'd do it more as a happy hour drink and appetizer type deal before a more substantial meal.

4f57-MyZ6XYFov-C4JTzfA.text: We order 5 appetizers and 12 tapas style meals to share.  Great good, great wine, great services. Found it a bit loud to have conversation with larger group.  Nice place!

728nnQF3fXj57fyiKscDuw.text: I had a rather odd experience.  I came after the Dianna Ross concert, and asked about the patio.  There were two hostesses, and they said the patio was closed because of the wind.  They could only seat me at the bar or high-tables at the bar. Not my preference. At the end of the dinner, I walked to the back of the restaurant to see the patio.  To my surprise, there were plenty of people there, and it was enclosed with glass panels. There were certainly some empty tables where I could have been seated.  My server, Jennie was very pleasant. I had the bacon-wrapped dates ($14). Delicious, but could be a difficult meal if you were trying to impress a companion as the dates and bacon were stringy.  I also had the scallops ($18). They were moist and very good, but only two on a slaw that was not that impressive and with some unexpected bacon bits.  La Violette Viognier was very good ($16). Again, everything was a bit pricey for what I got.  Next time, I'll try the Happy Hour.   Very strange experience, none-the-less.

fJ5BIW9ufCsfK5EKkXtdYw.text: We visited La Cave for the first time and were absolutely blown away! The restaurant is considered casual but it is a class act! The staff is friendly and attentive. The brunch buffet is $48 a person but the list of items is amazing. French Toast, Tomato Soup, Mushroom Grits, Eggs Benedict with Filet, etc. Everything is brought out by the staff, 'Butler-Style', fresh from the kitchen. So many choices we couldn't try all of them. They also have bottomless brunch cocktails for $20 a person. Margarita, Bloody Mary, Mimosa, Mojitos, etc. They have indoor and outdoor seating that overlooks the pool area. We will definitely be back for brunch again and can't wait to try dinner as well.

photos.caption: Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. La Cave
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. La Cave - Brunch Menu
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. La Cave

tCZ0S9PplEz2_kqfh3TzZA.text: In a nutshell the food is great but omg the service is the slowest on earth.  I took my bestie here for her birthday since she's a vegan and Wynn restaurants are known for their amazing Vegan menus. The menu definitely didn't fail to impress us.  We each ordered 3-4 items, since it's "tapas" style, but that was a TON of food.  We could've probably gotten away with 1-2 items each.  My main complaint is how SLOW the service is.  When we were first seated, the server greeted us and took my drink order. It took quite a while for the drink to come. Shortly after, we ordered food, and that took at least 30 minutes to come.  When we were done eating, we sat there for at least 20 minutes waiting for our server to bring the check. No one ever came to ask if we wanted water, or how we were doing. I was soooo irritated because at this point we were super stuffed and all I wanted to do was leave and go home to curl up in the fetal position.  Our server was super nice, but it seemed like maybe she had too many tables to tend to because after she took my card to pay for the check, it took her at least 10 more minutes to come back. So basically we sat there for an additional 30 minutes just waiting to check out. Waiting and suffering with our food babies in our bellies.    If you're a Vegan and want to do a special night out, I'd definitely recommend it because they have great options and it's definitely a special occasion type of place. If you're not a Vegan, there's lots of other options with amazing food and much better/timelier service.

photos.caption: Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Alfredo with bacon and an egg, OMG soooo good
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Vegan pizza
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Steak

jHm4PVMup8VLsRuZlwh-sA.text: Amazing atmosphere.  Superior wine selection.  I had the red gems (complete with an Opus One!).  Everything was magnificent except that my wife slipped on a small pool of water near some steps, and fell down.  Guests helped her back to her feet, but she was embarrassed and in pain the rest of the evening.  Nobody from the restaurant (and they all saw it) came to us and asked if she was okay, or if she would like anything at all.  So for that reason, I must withhold the 5th star.    Otherwise, this place is a must see.  Sit outside on the patio overlooking the garden and the Wynn hotel.  It's breathtaking.  Just watch your step inside!

2hcL3RZ4ejm7ycOVcKnN1w.text: The ambiance is very nice and the menu is excellent. Unfortunately the service was mediocre and left a shadow over the whole experience. Our inability get coffee refills was very frustrating. The two refills we obtained only came after making special requests and the second time required an additional reminder. Our table was a small two top which did not leave a lot of room for extra plates. Getting leftover dishes removed required flagging Busboys- they were not taken automatically. I could chalk some of these up to uncertainty if a dish was finished, but there were many clearly ready to be taken away. After we had been sitting for almost an hour, there were three core breakfast dishes that we still had not seen. Upon mentioning this to our server she agreed to look into their status. The hash showed up promptly but the other two remaining dishes did not appear until 12 minutes later. (I know this because I began to start looking at my watch) By that point I was full and ready to leave but since the effort was made to get them to the table, I felt obliged to have at least a bite or two. They were good and I would have enjoyed them if the timing had been better. We then paid and started to leave. On the way out I encountered the manager. We made eye contact and I nodded unsmiling hoping he would ask how the experience was. He did acknowledge me, but only to say Happy Easter. This had all the makings of a great experience. Poor execution prevented it.

LWibv3RQ7T2mbxcb3hrTqg.text: This place is unreal. So intimate, romantic and trendy. I loved it. There were couples and groups sharing the space and I still felt like like it wasn't crowded or we were crowded by others. They keep the lights dim which really adds to the ambience. We order a bunch of tapas- all made my mouth water and none of it seemed like it was enough- but I didn't leave hungry. My favorite were the bacon wrapped dates with a blue cheese fondue.  Literally every bite was delectable and made me hmm my approval!  Our server was knowledgeable made great recommendations without being pushy and was just a nice guy.  I would say it's great for a special occasion but you're already in Vegas- everything is a special occasion.

o8UtWi_5fVwRWgc8orTwNQ.text: This review is only for their brunch. It was okay. Nothing special, but for a price that suggests special should be expected.  Service was perfectly fine, there were regular offerings of dishes moving around the room. But the dishes themselves were quite average. Seemed to have a heavy reliance on scrambled eggs with onions. I wouldn't steer people away from here - in fact, we will likely return to try them out for a later-in-the-day meal. But for brunch, this wouldn't crack my Top 10 list - there are simply too many other better options in the area.

X2fSM7Hm9D7_LZTT3BJDoA.text: It's just incredible food the salads are really good you honestly can't go wrong with any of the choices we nearly tried the whole menu and everything was so good and the Decour is so pretty the price is not too bad either

MG_4rvCh00TvQPPkg0lpuA.text: The location and food is amazing! Servers were great too but the management has no clue on how to treat customers - rude and insulting.

fCZFGPgUqTN7Gs85jgjB4Q.text: The waiter and the manger had a real attitude problem. In the capital of good customer service, this place was abysmal. We were a group of 10 and the waiter couldn't get us individual checks and it took 30 minutes to bring us separate checks and lots of making faces because it was so inconvenient to him. And when we arrived the waiter asked if we got a table or seats and we said seats. One would think seats meant separate checks. And even worse the manager chased us down after we left for a missing credit card receipt. Yeah, that's because one of us paid with cash. The manager also yelled obscenities behind our back. Food was decent and wine was good but the service was terrible. With so many other great food options on the strip that have good service as well, there is not a way any of us will ever go back.

klSA2CbF7N_YSsJHTfCxOA.text: I've been here for dinner many moons ago and it was a great experience. I went here for brunch for Easter and I'm glad I did. I think I enjoyed their brunch menu more than their dinner menu.  For about $50, you can enjoy 16 butler-style table side items and for an additional $20, you get unlimited brunch cocktails (mimosa, sangria, Mojito, margarita, Bloody Mary, and caipiranha). About $30 for kids under 12. Servers with plates/trays of food go around the restaurant. We were sitting in front of the kitchen so, we always got first dibs on everything.  Items we got just for the heck of it (non mind-blowing but expectations weren't set high in the first place): Heirloom Tomato and Mozzarella Salad Fresh Fruit Salad Scrambled Eggs Angus Mini Burger Chorizo Sausage Cup Pancakes with Berry Compote Tomato Mozzarella Flatbread Veal Short Rib Hash  What we enjoyed and ate the most: Cornflake Crusted Brioche French Toast Mushroom Grits (I smelled truffles when the server passed by so, I had to have this!) Baked Potato Loaded Tater Tots with Brown Gravy (do you like Poutine?) Ham and Egg Flatbread (raw quail eggs) Eggs Benedict with Chorizo (one of the best eggs Benedict's I've ever consumed) Eggs Benedict with Filet (you can't go wrong with steak and eggs)  This is supposed to be a leisurely dining experience so, if you have to be somewhere at a certain time, go somewhere else. I like my Lazy Sundays so this was an excellent choice. Laidback, no worries...just sit, eat, sip and enjoy life!

photos.caption: Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tater Tots
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Eggs Benedict with Steak
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Eggs Benedict with Chorizo

Kju59HttwPN--rNzNwIhZw.text: This was probably one of the most expensive places we ate during our exploration of food. They serve food in small tastings. We got 4 plates. One was mini sliders. Another was scallops on fried polenta. The other was bacon and egg fettuccine  prosciutto. The last was mushroom grits with truffle and pecorino.  They were all very delicious. Our waitress was extremely attentive and friendly. Our view was simply divine. I think it was a perfect experience and I would definitely return to try out more of these little bites. This restaurant is back a little from the machines. You have to look for it. We had a table outside and were by ourselves for most of our meal. I have to say for my one venture outside of Palazzo that we did have a great time.

photos.caption: Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu

UZN5FzoOth5KIOtqip92Qw.text: We came here for brunch which was so good we came back for dinner. Our server Matt had great suggestions on the menu from bacon wrapped dates to an incredible onion pastry soup. Followed up with Gorgonzola Bibb salad and salmon and some excellent wines from their extensive list.   Be sure to save room for beignets and some 20 year port for dessert!  Excellent meal and service (ask to sit outside) and we will be back!

photos.caption: Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Onion in pastry soup
Photo of La Cave Wine and Food Hideaway - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Salmon with fennel

PaIfuyaMTokMjsZ2TkmoVw.text: I recently celebrated my birthday at La Cave and was very impressed. The restaurant is absolutely beautiful. As the name suggests, they have a dim "hide away" vibe that projects an understated and intimate elegance.   Our server was great - very attentive and polite. He knew the menu well and was able to make great recommendations.   The food at La Cave is easily some of the best in town. My party of three shared four dishes (tapas style) and they were all excellent. We had a field greens salad with champagne vinaigrette, tomato and mozzarella flatbread with capers, roasted salmon with green beans, and a chicken pesto pasta. Throughout the meal, we literally couldn't stop talking about how great everything was.   For a nice restaurant on the strip, the prices were quite reasonable. For the four dishes and a glass of wine each, it came out to about $45/person including tip.

XTGeOMgVhvdI_E2_Vr931Q.text: As people have said, it's a little pricey but it was very good. Charcuterie was really great. The tables were a little too close together but overall it was very good. We will come back.

84xD5zKQqzNEAhsJ8Wc8yw.text: Another small plates joint.  I love small plates and sharing.  I also love enomatic machines.  They ensure that the wine comes out at the right temperature.  Red wine is always served too warm.  I had the Blue-Eyed Boy Shiraz by Mollydooker and a nice Malbec.  Both were excellent.  Some of the wines are not served in the enomatic machine.  Make sure to order from the enomatic machine.  And ignore the $120 glass of wine.  I don't know what's up with that.  The rest of their wine is reasonably priced.  Our bartender, turned server as the night went on, was also excellent. Very attentive and anticipated our needs. We tried the bacon wrapped dates, mushroom grits, and the prosciutto flatbread.  I could have lived without the bacon-wrapped dates... too large and mushy. you have to cut them in half to eat them. The blue cheese fondue the dates came with didn't have much flavor to it.  I like Firefly's bacon-wrapped dates better with the almond in the middle for some crunch.  I think our bartender did too, because he asked if we'd tried Firefly's.  The mushroom grits were to die for... so tasty with the truffle oil.  I adore grits.  And the prosciutto flatbread was also very, very good.  Lots of prosciutto with arugula made for a nice balance of flavors.  The flatbread is huge compared to the other dishes, so beware.  The desserts were ok. There was a toasted poundcake with strawberry and sour cream ice cream that sounded great but turned out to be underwhelming.  The poundcake just tasted stale and the sour cream ice cream just tasted like vanilla.  We also tried the beignets which were just beignets.  Nothing to write home about.  I like the ambience, but I would suggest sitting farther away from the door.  Maybe at the bar in the back or at a table.  At one point, these kids coming from the pool in swimsuits decided to play in the revolving glass door... and the hostess and their mom let them.  In about 1 minute, one of the kids got slammed in the door by the other kids.  Screaming ensued. The mom couldn't figure out how to get the kid out of the revolving door for a while.  So annoying.  I think the hostess should have put a stop to that before it happened.  It was pretty predictable.  Later in the evening some drunk guys in t-shirts and shorts came in, falling all over the place and asking for Coors Light.  Charming.  Just get a table in the back if you are looking for ambiance that does not involve the regular Las Vegas tourist.   It's a cute spot that has potential.

BytNJgkMj2l9-G9NwOj_iQ.text: We can here as a group of 8 and got an amazing table in the back room and the services was spectacular. What surprised me the most are the totally fair portion sizes - we followed the 2 per person and everyone was stuffed (with a few plates leftover). The items that really stood out: - Thai basil chicken flatbread: We ordered three varieties of flatbreads and this was one immediately consumed. - Three bean salad: delicious - Ahi tuna: amazing - Onion soup: while Delicious, definitely not a sharing dish. - Sirloin steak: tasty - Shrimp: tasty - Steak fillet: tasty - Mini burgers: tasty (pretty much all the red meat delicious were yummy)  Other items ordered: - Snapper ceviche: was just meh  - Bacon flatbread: I know this is going to sound crazy but way too bacon-y (it's possible) - Salmon sashimi: was good but nothing we'd order again  I would definitely come back and would recommend this place to others. Perfect for groups or a romantic date.

vrfrVTZsN1Oh1Ns30MhbCQ.text: Aaron, Tracy, and Ralph made us feel so welcome and this was by far the greatest experience I have ever had at any restaurant. Everything we ordered looked just as good as it tasted. The wine and beer selection was diverse and impressive. I can't even pick a favorite dish because everything was perfect. Must try: Mushroom grits, tomato caper flatbread, jumbo lump crab lettuce cups, and wagyu skirt steak. I will recommend this to everyone who comes to Las Vegas and I will be returning every time I visit.

52cm2oFFVlPfCxshnfGPKw.text: Alright, first off, this is not a restaurant you go to and expect to eat your own meals. This restaurant is meant to be a really fancy take on family dinner. The food comes out on small plates in modest portions abs you are encouraged to share. So you are also encouraged to get a few plates of food not just one for yourself to enjoy as you would in a normal restaurant.   All that being said, this place is really good. With the portion sizes being small it isnt overwhelming and you don't leave over full. We had the chicken skewers, shrimp, Angus, and the benigets.   The chicken came on skewers with little toasted pita slices with a taziki sauce. (like the stuff you get on gyros) the chicken was moist and the sauce very good.   The shrimp was wonderful and the sauce was very creole in taste but not overly spicey.  The Angus came out about the size of a fist and cut into two pieces. It also was very flavorful but wasn't cooked as well as I could have been I think.  The benigets were small abs round, like a Mexican wedding cake, and came with a chocolate sauce, raspberry jam and a cream sauce I cannot place. All were just wonderful.   So if you're looking for something a little different with delicious food this is a good place to eat. If you're super hungry and not wanting share go someplace else.   Our waiter was very friendly and knowledgeable of the menu as there were a lot of words I didn't personally recognize on there lol.

1qeVWSPZd4Q-03SMcDhBsw.text: Went there for dinner after attending the Wynn Showstoppers show. The venue was super nice - especially the terrace looking out to the frondous hotel grounds. We were however overall disappointed with the quality of the food. Our Gorgonzola salad tasted flat - quite the opposite of what you'd expect (desire) in a Gorgonzola dish - and some of the bits and pieces in it were hard to identify (whether by eyesight or by tastebuds). The ceviche was alright due to its fresh cilantro seasoning but otherwise lacked freshness and lemony zing. The mini burgers' meat was super tasty, but such taste was slightly damped by the mushroomy tapenade that coated it - and the bread was neutral in the palest possible way. The redeeming dish was definitely the tomato mozzarella and capers flatbread - flavorful and crisp although it would have benefited from being served a bit hotter to get more of the "fresh out of the oven" feel.  The wine list was extensive and it was a nice surprise to get a Verdejo option - I love this Spanish grape.  My margarita however tasted like anything but - not sure what they put in it but it felt more like drinking a watery mezcal mix. It may be that we weren't lucky with our food choices and I'd give this venue another try - just.

rgQr-XDlqqjqDaA8OvN5vw.text: Loved it here! There's a couple items I could've done with out including the Moroccan chicken skewers and the salmon. The salmon was very plain for all the "dressings" and the chicken was dry and plain even with the tzatziki. That's the only negatives I have. We had everything from the beef filet crostini to the Gorgonzola salad, sliders, ceviche, onion soup, bacon wrapped dates, and three diff flatbreads- Thai chicken, steak and mushroom, and chorizo and sausage. All were completely up to par. Nice atmosphere and good food to compliment. The portions are all tapas but VERY filling and satisfying. Will definitely return. Beignets were decent but the smores flatbread was amazing not overly rich but absolutely got the point across. We had two young kids With us and even though my kids do extremely well I think it's more suitable for adults for sure, it's just more intimidate yet casual. Good for some wine and tapas with friends or a nice date night. If u do happen have children with you, they definitely cater just fine and don't make you feel out of place.

w51j2k2LjnJzVVEUS37dkQ.text: La Cave was ok. Was it terrible? No. But it definitely didn't blow us away. We had the bacon wrapped dates (frankly our local restaurant at home does them way better) and Moroccan chicken first. The chicken was very hot spicy but relatively little flavor to the spice. All heat. We also had the beef filet crostini, which were fine but not remarkable. The one we liked the best (which really isn't saying much considering the overall experience) is the lamb tenderloin. My other half had the cucumber lemonade, which was quite good.   I like the tapas approach, but the plates were definitely spendy for what you got.

xTl3JNZ2iEqpdAqdYd8pgQ.text: Great service, food and drinks. I had the three bean salad and the Gardein chicken. Both off the vegan menu. Both were excellent! I even had to have my husband try my faux chicken because it looked a little too much like chicken. It ended up being one of the best vegan dishes I've ever had. I recommend sitting outside because their patio was very beautiful and quite cozy.

-v_Q0xMN2lyeJpA5VeACJA.text: Awesome small bites and ambience, nice patio seating available.  Tried the Thai Snapper Ceviche, Jumbo Lump Crab Lettuce Cups, Diver Sea Scallops, Beef Filet and Mini Burgers (mushroom) - everything was beyond delicious!

2dp03HOafq3C6RUh0-yEhQ.text: Delicious, creative dishes in a gorgeous space tucked inside the Wynn.  The best part about coming with a big group (we had 8) is being able to basically sample the whole menu...which we pretty much did. That being said, La Cave is a place that I like to classify as a great "girls night" restaurant because the tapas sized portions don't really compare to a good ol' steak and eggs at Buffalo Bills; unless you're willing to drop $70+ on food per person (not including drinks), you probably won't leave full.  Expect to order at least 2 of every dish if you have a party of more than 5.  The food was excellent overall. Some of my favourites were the bacon, egg, and fontina flatbread, the diver sea scallops, and the short rib cavatelli (which in a twisted way tasted like Chef Boyardee's beefaroni, but in the best way possible). Another big hit was the beignets, or more specifically, the creme anglaise that came with it....long after the beignets were gone, we were still scraping up the creme anglaise. Some "meh" dishes were the shrimp with piquillo peppers, the jumbo crab lettuce cups, and the bacon wrapped dates, but I only say they're "meh" because they didn't do these dishes any better than anywhere else that serves them.   Because the menu is extensive and the portions small, your best bet would be to ask the waiter for his/her recommendations and take it from there. Hopefully, your waiter will be a bit more opinionated than ours (when we asked her for recommendations, she waffled on every suggestion so I ended up taking the reins and ordering everything myself).

a8iPOB1Q6U6uUpP4oOyMxw.text: Our absolute favorite brunch spot, anywhere. I love the butler style service (small plates that come to your table to choose from). It allows a nice strolling brunch. My favorite choices are the breakfast pizza (would have never expected to like that) and mushroom grits. Bottomless drinks with a selection that you can choose from and rotate through is a definite bonus. Also, their patio is beautiful! Rfd service sometimes is slow (for food) depending on how busy they are, but we're never in a hurry hear because we love soaking up this place.

2h4GWnI0ssf71-L4pJOnRA.text: La Cave is a great spot to eat.  I love the atmosphere here.  Food was great too!  We had:  Mixed Greens Mushroom Grits Onion Soup Thai Snapper Ceviche Hamachi Beef Carpaccio Cavatelli Fiery Artichoke, Roasted Pepper, Olives Flatbread Beef Filet, Caramelized Onions, Mushrooms, Blue Cheese Flatbread Angus Mini Burgers

R3XlV1ZqTpw4LRC1P2D1hQ.text: Loved the tapas sized plates.   Don't miss the Thai chicken flatbread.  I also loved the cheese course.

LPcFkWGWSMuobcbVY9DDnw.text: Not worth it.  Flavorless,  overpriced,  poor presentation.  We had the ceviche (best dish of the 4), ahi blah,  grilled shrimp really gross,  and kale salad had better at whole foods.  This is not a 5 star dining experience.  Weak cocktails.  Ambiance is gorgeous,  sat on the patio, worthy of one star.   I don't get the hype... Maybe I wasn't drunk enough.

6Epq0LP1fRUp8MeYjAIzGA.text: We brought an important client here and were right on time for our reservation.  Hostess brings us outside and it's over 100 degrees so we ask to be seated inside.  She tells us they don't have any tables so we'll have to sit outside until something becomes available.  Waitress comes out and could care less that we are unhappy.  After half an hour we finally give up and just decide to eat outside.  An hour later as we're half way through our entrees she comes out with "Great news!  We have a table inside!"  Are you freakin kidding me?  We all laugh and say forget it.  No apology, no free drink, nothing.  Will not be returning to drop another $500 to sweat through dinner and feel totally unappreciated.

LPAQ91-dfgqaWrIHWD_ceQ.text: I'm a sucker for a good wine bar, and this place is now in the running for my favorite one in Vegas!   *Atmosphere - we sat in the beautiful back "sun room". It had an almost Moroccan feel to it with nice brown tones and a huge planter built into the wall overflowing with greenery. Floor to ceiling windows, comfy furniture.. I loved it! It was a nice contrast from the more cave-like room in the front.   *Wine - The wines by the glass weren't all that exciting to me, but we had a couple of half bottles. They were stupid expensive ($50?), but it's the Wynn, I can't say I was surprised.   *Staff - weird, honestly. The waiter was aloof and the hostess had to get my name and whether I was staying at the Wynn or not down on some piece of paper before I was allowed to sit down in the empty restaurant. We were also told we could only have the table for an hour, but whatever. The bus boys tried to pick up our water glasses and remove them several times. It was bordering on silly.   *Food - I adore meat and cheese and this place had a phenomenal meat and cheese list. Reasonable portions were $5 or so, not all that bad. We had an aged gouda, proscuitto, and truffled goat cheese. Seriously some of the best cheese I've ever had! So freaking yummy.   This was a great place for a pre-dinner drink and snack, but would also be a fun place to end the evening. Sexy enough for a date, but also fun for a group of ladies - one of my new favorite spots to drink on the strip.

ud4XI198UVyCk8yqherVbw.text: We came back 4 years later after enjoying the ambiance the first time. This time the service was quick and the food was good but we were unable to be seated outside and the ambiance was not as good. Overall still a good restaurant but outside seating is nicer.

g3p2jc83GR7i_o3RwMxBfg.text: Had lunch here on a Friday afternoon ...  Ok.. so what's up with needing my first and last name before seating me?  It's not like it was used in any way to speak to me during my visit here.  Anyways...  SCENE:  Great vibe... really cool bar in the front area... cool bar in the back area Low lighting, dark, modern, upscale cave like feel... kinda romantic without being gushy...I guess you might call it 'casual-intimate'.  Good place to hang out with friends or work friends ...but not a good place for a power lunch.  There's a patio area with nice looking couches, chairs, tables, live plants, and really nice (fancy) looking hammock chairs.  They just begged to be sat in with a glass of wine and enjoy the day.  However, it was a bit chilly and they didn't have outdoor heaters out there so we sat inside.  SERVICE:  For a Wynn establishment... I expected more / better.  I'm not saying it was 'Bad'... it was just Mediocre which is NOT how you would think anything at Wynn would be.  We were sat immediately but the wine menu was not part of the menus provided.  I mean... they give you an additional menu that is sorted by Gluten-Free or Dairy-Free or Meat-Free, etc.... but they don't give you a Wine menu?  Hello... you're surrounded by wine and isn't this supposed to be like a really nice wine bar?  So... after waiting for 5-7 minutes to gain the attention of anyone... we asked for a wine menu.  And it's a very nice wine menu.... not ridiculously priced and they have a good selection of different priced wines.   We ended up ordering a glass each... by the glass ranges from about $10-20 depending.  Not cheap... Not atrocious.  FOOD: The Fiery Artichoke Flatbread is FANTASTIC!  Comes with fresh ricotta, roasted red peppers, pepperocini and of course artichokes.  The flavors went really well together and the ricotta was like butter.  The bread itself was perfect!  Not dough-y and not tough.  The Beet dish is really good... very rich because of the melted goat cheese, but so YUMMY!  The beets were juicy yet firm.  The Asparagus dish was 'ok'... I don't think I'd order it again... it came with shaved hard boiled egg and crispy pancetta.  It sounded good on the menu but the flavors did not blend together well.  And they put some sort of lemon or citrus sauce on it which made it too sour-like.  The Dates were 'ok'..... I've had better.  I think it's because the bacon they used was not of the Applewood Smoke type and that the blue cheese fondue (on the side) was really runny.... versus being melted inside the date.  Anyways...overall... Yes, it's a bit pricey... $76 b/4 tax... for 2 people with a glass of wine each... but it's a really lovely meal.  If I go back... I intend on sitting on the patio and being able to savor the experience better.

gCu2sWlnCqr73ZxQkRUO_g.text: Really enjoyed the butler-served ayce Sunday brunch. Thought it was a great value, and food delish. Also thought the bottomless cocktails for $20 a person were a great value- they had a nice little list of classic cocktails and you could a pick a different one for each refill if desired. Really lovely, would go again!

Psz0nowgLGZjaSzb5hSxJQ.text: Four of us went to La Cave for brunch today. The food overall was good. The eggs Benedict was a miss. No flavor. The grits and Tatar tots were a hit. The service was wonderful. I don't know why so few people were there. We lingered over Sparkling wine for hours in a lovely atmosphere.

NAfrcMzapRMvJ54OrwZyzg.text: Per my galpal from Colorado's request to try a fine-dining meal together during her visit to Vegas, I did my research and thanks to these magnificent yelpers for their recommendations, we ended up opting for La Cave at the Wynn for dinner.   We were tight with time and had quite a struggle getting a ringside table at Olives (located at the Bellagio) because apparently, making a reservation in the morning doesn't guarantee you a spot for the night. It's just that in demand! So we stuck with a 10pm reservation there and a 7:15pm reservation here at La Cave. As the day progressed (this was on Saturday), we had to buy more time to squeeze in other stuff to do for the day and realized we would not be able to make it in time here. Fortunately, La Cave had another opening at 9pm and were accomodating enough to push us back, plus leave our table open for 15-20 minutes to make it even more flexible. We got there just in time to be welcomed by some friendly usherettes who led us to a nice high table in the most cozy-looking restaurant, dimly lit with lines and lines of wine bottles ranging from varieties made as recent as last year to vintage wine (I think the most expensive bottle I saw was priced at almost $500)  We enjoyed the most nicely presented food I've ever seen (Naturally, considering this was my first fine-dining experience). The portions were just as cute, enough to fill our tummies. And to think that I should've splurged at this opportunity, I actually ended up with a health-conscious choice of roasted salmon with vegetable pasta and yellow tomato broth for $16. That and a glass of water. Our server was patient enough to split our checks for the night and we were prepped and contented. Was a long night of great conversations despite the chitter-chatter in the background seeing as how the restaurant was packed. The atmosphere had such a classy vibe to it, totally worth dressing up for.
